[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Function: AssertValidFeeToken()] [DOS Attack] GetTokenInfo at line 126 might be an expensive operation - can an attacker call SetMethodFee with many tokens to DOS this validation loop? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Function: AssertValidFeeToken()] [Null Handling] If GetTokenInfo returns null at line 127, an AssertionException is thrown at line 129 - can this be exploited to revert legitimate fee setting operations? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Function: AssertValidFeeToken()] [Token Property] The check at line 131 requires tokenInfo.IsBurnable to be true - can an attacker create a token that reports IsBurnable as true but fails during actual burn operations, causing fee collection failures? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Function: AssertValidFeeToken()] [Error Message] The error message at line 131 only mentions the symbol - should it also validate that the token has sufficient properties for method fee usage beyond burnability? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Functions: SetMethodFee + GetMethodFee] [State Inconsistency] Can an attacker exploit timing between SetMethodFee writing at line 20 and GetMethodFee reading at line 50 to cause inconsistent fee calculations across transactions? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Functions: SetMethodFee + GetTransactionFeeSymbols] [DOS Attack] If SetMethodFee allows setting unlimited fee symbols, can GetTransactionFeeSymbols at lines 69-82 run out of gas when called during actual transaction fee charging? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Functions: ChangeMethodFeeController + SetMethodFee] [Race Condition] Can an attacker sandwich a ChangeMethodFeeController call between two SetMethodFee calls to manipulate fees during controller transition? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Functions: RequiredMethodFeeControllerSet + ChangeMethodFeeController] [Initialization Attack] Can RequiredMethodFeeControllerSet at line 91 be called during ChangeMethodFeeController execution to reset the controller to default, bypassing authorization? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Functions: All] [Global DOS] Can setting method fees for critical internal methods like GetMethodFee or GetMethodFeeController create circular dependency DOS where querying fees requires paying fees? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [State: State.TransactionFees] [Unbounded Growth] State.TransactionFees is accessed at line 20 and 50 - is there a limit on how many different methodNames can be stored, or can an attacker fill storage with unlimited entries? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [State: State.MethodFeeController] [Single Point of Failure] State.MethodFeeController controls all fee settings - if this is compromised via ChangeMethodFeeController, can an attacker permanently DOS the contract by setting impossible fees? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [State: State.ParliamentContract] [Address Caching] State.ParliamentContract.Value is cached at line 95 - if the Parliament contract is upgraded, does this cache become stale, causing RequiredMethodFeeControllerSet to use the wrong contract? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [State: State.SymbolListToPayTxSizeFee] [Null State] State.SymbolListToPayTxSizeFee.Value can be null at line 80 - can this state be manipulated to permanently disable size fee collection? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Input: MethodFees.MethodName] [Missing Validation] SetMethodFee at line 20 stores input.MethodName without validating it's a real contract method - can an attacker set fees for non-existent methods to waste storage? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Input: MethodFees.Fees] [Array Size] SetMethodFee iterates input.Fees at line 15 - is there a maximum array size check, or can an attacker provide thousands of entries to DOS the validation loop? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Input: MethodFees.IsSizeFeeFree] [Boolean Manipulation] GetMethodFee checks IsSizeFeeFree at line 74 - can this flag be set arbitrarily in SetMethodFee to bypass size fees for methods that should charge them? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Input: AuthorityInfo] [Missing Field Validation] ChangeMethodFeeController accepts AuthorityInfo at line 24 - are both ContractAddress and OwnerAddress validated for non-zero values before line 31? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Input: StringValue] [String Length] GetMethodFee receives StringValue.Value at line 37 - is there a maximum string length check before using it in Contains at line 44? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Economic: Fee Manipulation] [Supply Attack] Can the controller set method fees in tokens they control the supply of, then manipulate token supply to make fees impossible to pay, DOS'ing the contract? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Economic: Fee Collection] [Revenue Loss] If AssertValidFeeToken at line 123 validates burnable tokens, but fee collection burns fees, can the controller set fees that drain user funds without protocol benefit? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Economic: Fee Structure] [Unequal Burden] Can the controller set different fee structures for economically equivalent operations (e.g., Transfer vs TransferFrom) to create arbitrage or unfair burden? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Economic: Size Fee] [Fee Evasion] GetTransactionFeeSymbols returns size fee symbols at line 82 - can users structure transactions to minimize size fees while performing the same operations? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Governance: Controller Capture] [Hostile Takeover] If the Parliament contract used in RequiredMethodFeeControllerSet at line 104 is compromised, can an attacker become the default organization and control all fees? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Governance: Proposal Bypass] [Direct Control] ChangeMethodFeeController checks organization existence at line 28 but not proposal requirements - can an attacker with organization control change fees without proposal voting? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_ACS1_MethodFeeProvider.cs] [Governance: Emergency Response] [No Emergency Stop] There's no emergency stop mechanism in SetMethodFee or ChangeMethodFeeController - if fees are set maliciously, how can they be reverted quickly? (High)
